item.title: This Windows gaming handheld has a screen that folds in half
item.content:encoded:
Lenovo put a foldable display on a gaming handheld. The Legion Go Fold Concept is a Windows-based handheld with a flexible POLED display, detachable Joy-Con-like controllers, and a folio case to turn the whole thing into a mini laptop.

You can use it as a standard Steam Deck-esque handheld with the display folded down to 7.7 inches and controllers attached at its sides, or you can unfold it for a bigger experience. When unfolded, the controllers can be repositioned to all four sides, allowing you to play with the screen in vertical or horizontal orientations.

In vertical splitscreen mode, you can put your game on one half of the screen and a second window (like your chat or game guide) on the other half. Horizontal fullscreen mode gives your game the full 11.6 inches of real estate in a 16:10 aspect ratio. To go into laptop mode, you remove the controllers and mount the handheld into a folio case with a stand, built-in keyboard, and trackpad. The controllers can be put into a separate grip mount to unify them as one gamepad.

1/4

There are a lot of ways you can use this folding handheld, including turning one of its controllers into a vertical mouse like on other Legion Go handhelds, but there‚Äôs one thing it doesn‚Äôt do: fold down to close and protect its screen. The Go Fold only folds outwards, so don‚Äôt expect a Nintendo DS or GameBoy Advance-like clamshell that closes for portability. Instead, it‚Äôs all about getting bigger than your average gaming handheld and offering more. (Though we‚Äôve tried bigger before.)

The Legion Go Fold has some formidable specs: an Intel Core Ultra 7 258V Lunar Lake processor, 32GB of RAM, 1TB of storage, and a 48Whr battery. The plastic-covered OLED has a resolution of 2435 x 1712 and 165Hz refresh rate. And there‚Äôs even a second, circular toushscreen on the right controller, under the face buttons. It doubles as a touchpad and can be a support display, allowing you to swipe between extracted UI elements from a game (which I wouldn‚Äôt expect to be widely supported), a clock, system monitoring, or an animated GIF (just for fun).

1/13

During my brief in-person demo I didn‚Äôt get to play any graphically-intense games ‚Äî just Balatro, which can practically play on a potato. The screen looked plenty sharp, but like any foldable there‚Äôs a crease down the middle; it‚Äôs very visible, but you learn to look past it and ignore it after just a bit. The build and feel of the whole thing felt a little fragile, and detaching and reattaching the controllers was definitely janky. Build quality will hopefully be improved if this device ever actually makes it to market.

The laptop mode was a pleasant surprise for me though. I did not expect a gaming handheld to double as a conventional computer you could get work done on. The Legion Go Fold‚Äôs case took quite a bit of fumbling before I set it up correctly, but it shouldn‚Äôt take too long to get used to if you actually lived with it.

Then again, I don‚Äôt know if anyone is going to be able to live with this thing ‚Äî ever. I‚Äôd love for the Legion Go Fold to go from concept to real product like other out-there Lenovo ideas, but I shudder to think what it might cost. The Legion Go 2 is already priced well over $1,000. And with the ongoing RAMageddon crisis we‚Äôre living through, there‚Äôs no telling how much more expensive an actual Legion Go Fold would be if it came out in a year or more.

But even if it‚Äôs not the kind of foldable I expected, and even though it may never come out, it‚Äôs certainly cool. Now somebody please make a folding PC handheld that goes from kinda-big to really small. I think that‚Äôd be the one for me.

item.title: Fans Speculate a Krato-less God of War Spin-Off is in the Works
item.content:encoded:
While God of War Ragnar√∂k came out in 2022, the series as a whole has hardly been in Odinsleep. From remasters to new games and cancelled ones, much has stirred in Kratos‚Äô mythological realm. After spotting a now-deleted LinkedIn page regarding Sony Santa Monica Studio, fans believe a big new God of War game is in the works, albeit one without its titular vengeance-seeker.

The page from a Senior Writer at Sony Interactive Entertainment says they ‚ÄúHelped shape narrative vision and creative direction for a new franchise within the God of War universe‚Äù and ended their time at the studio last September. While speculative threads on ResetEra don‚Äôt hold much water on their own, reporter and industry fortune-teller Jason Schreier chimed in, posting ‚ÄúI suppose now it‚Äôs become obvious what I meant by ‚Äònot a new IP but it might feel like one.'‚Äù

It‚Äôs been a busy month for the ol‚Äô God of War. During the most recent State of Play, Sony unveiled a remake for the entire original trilogy of games, in which Kratos cleaves the entire Greek pantheon from Hades to Olympus. It was paired with a surprise 2D prequel, Sons of Sparta, which dropped that same day. On the other end, Sony shuttered Bluepoint Games, who recently saw their live-service God of War spin-off cancelled following the dramatic fall of Concord. Somewhere in the middle, the first glimpse at Amazon‚Äôs live-action adaptation dropped online, leaving fans to contend with something that resembles a Super Bowl commercial.

Prequels and adaptations address the past and present for God of War, but what does that leave for the future? Schreier‚Äôs recent post about a new-but-not-new IP seems to refer to one made last July, in which he scratched out a rumor that Cory Barlog was developing a new sci-fi adventure. Put together, these two posts suggest that new IP and this spin-off are one in the same. This new game might see another dramatic departure, not only from the series‚Äô main protagonist but its genre as well, similar to when God of War descended from a frenzied Devil May Cry hack-em-up to an over the shoulder affair. It would certainly be more consistent for Sony, who seem more eager to tease out their existing characters with spin-offs, cross-media adaptations, live-service games and self-congratulatory cameos than develop something new.

item.title: Zelda Voice Actress Discusses Creative Direction in Audition
item.content:encoded:
The voice behind Princess Zelda discusses the direction and expectations, or lackthereof, she was given during her audition.

Patricia Summersett has been the English voice of Princess Zelda since the release of The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild in 2017. Now, she‚Äôs opening up about the audition process, the direction she was given by Nintendo, and more.

Summersett Was Given ‚ÄòBleached Script‚Äô Ahead of Casting

In an interview with IGN, Patricia Summersett explained that she was given a bleached script when first auditioning for the role. This means that she was given limited information about the role she was auditioning for and didn‚Äôt actually know she was attempting to provide the voice for one of gaming‚Äôs most iconic characters.

Summersett was given the description of Zelda as a younger teenage princess who is wise beyond her years. She was also told that the character had the weight of the world thrust upon her.

‚ÄúThose were key things I‚Äôd gone into when I looked at the script, when I started to play around with my voice and decide what to do for that particular character,‚Äù she said.

Additionally, Summersett reveals that she‚Äôd also tried out for other roles in the game, one of which ended up being Urbosa.

Summersett Views Her Zelda Accent As Hylian

As for Zelda having a British accent, Summersett revealed that it was not a note from Nintendo. Rather, it was a choice she made on her own.

‚ÄúI schooled in London and so I thought something that sounds a little bit RP would make it heightened and put it into that kind of class system I was imagining for royalty. So I did that,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a little more comfortable to say this is a Hylian accent versus just a particular version of a UK accent.‚Äù

item.title: NVIDIA Warns of Tight Memory Supply for Coming Quarters
item.content:encoded:
NVIDIA‚Äôs CFO sets the stage for uncertainty about the company‚Äôs ability to grow in the gaming sector amid current memory shortages.

Currently, NVIDIA is reporting record growth following its Q4 earnings for fiscal year 2026. However, as the company moves toward a heavy focus on AI and data centers, rather than relying on gaming for the majority of its revenue, the question has been raised about whether it will continue to grow year over year in the forthcoming fiscal year.

NVIDIA CFO Cautions Investors on Gaming Growth Uncertainty

During an investor call following the release of their quarterly earnings, NVIDIA CFO Colette Kress was asked directly if she foresees a continued pattern of year-over-year growth in the next fiscal year.

In response, she said that, as much as the company would love to have an additional supply of memory, they expect things to be tight for the next ‚Äúcouple of quarters.‚Äù Therefore, it‚Äôs still too early to tell.

‚ÄúWe do believe for a couple of quarters, it is going to be very tight. If things improve by the end of the year, there is an opportunity to think about what that is from a year-over-year growth [angle], but it‚Äôs still too early for us to know at this time, and we‚Äôll get back to you as soon as we can,‚Äù she said.

NVIDIA Is Skipping Graphics Card Releases to Focus on AI

It was recently reported that NVIDIA was opting not to release new graphics cards this year. This isn‚Äôt a concerted effort to focus on AI chips and datacenters due to the RAM shortage. Additionally, the company plans on cutting production of the current RTX 50-series graphics cards due to the shortage. Learn more about that here.

item.title: NVIDIA Records Record Quarterly Growth, up 73% in Last Year
item.content:encoded:
NVIDIA reports unprecedented growth in its financial results for Q4 of the fiscal year 2026.

On February 25, NVIDIA announced its quarterly earnings for the quarter, which ended one month earlier. The company recorded revenue of $68.1 billion, up 20% from the previous quarter and 73% from this time last year. Also, total revenue for the fiscal year was $215.9 billion. That is a 65% increase from the prior year.

Data Center Growth Skyrockets for NVIDIA

As the AI boom continues to take shape, NVIDIA‚Äôs Q4 data center revenue was a record-setting $62.3 billion, up 22% from the previous quarter and 75% from last year. Their report attributes this growth to major platform shifts, specifically accelerated Computing and AI. Full-year data center revenue rose 68% to a record $193.7 billion.

Gaming Revenue Grows for NVIDIA

As for gaming revenue, Q4 saw a 47% year-over-year increase. Total gaming revenue for the quarter with $3.7 billion. However, while there was year-over-year growth, gaming and aipc revenue are actually down 13% from the previous quarter. That decrease is attributed to inventory naturally moderating following a season of strong holiday demand.

Jonathan Hobbs of IncomeShares noted that back in 2020, gaming was the largest revenue driver for NVIDIA. However, data centers now account for 90% of NVIDIA‚Äôs revenue, signaling the concentrated shift to AI.

The AI boom, leading to a RAM shortage, continues to loom over the future of gaming. Currently, it is expected that gamers may not see the PlayStation 6 until 2029. Even Microsoft does not want to commit to a 2027 launch window for its next console.

item.title: Marathon‚Äôs Server Slam Didn‚Äôt Gain Traction This Weekend, But It Still Topped Some Titans
item.content:encoded:
Marathon‚Äôs server slam started on Thursday, and within a couple of hours, hundreds of thousands of people had either downloaded it and started playing or started watching it on a streaming platform somewhere. It picked up pace, hit more than 143,000 concurrent players on Steam alone, and then promptly fizzled.

Within six hours, the peak dropped by 30,000 players, and by the following evening, it was peaking at half the original high. Many believed the weekend would yield some gains as players worldwide came off work and into Bungie‚Äôs Marathon, but it wasn‚Äôt to be. That being said, the server slam still managed to top some titans on Steam.

Marathon Could Go Either Way

Marathon didn‚Äôt make immense waves in the gaming space this weekend, but it still beat the likes of Battlefield 6 and Call of Duty.

It‚Äôs no big secret that these two titanic franchises have had their fair share of issues in the last few months. Black Ops 7 launched to a woeful reception and is suffering immensely at the hands of a disinterested community. On the other hand, Battlefield 6 continues to flounder amidst poor updates and a slow change cadence.

Marathon will be the ‚Äònew shiny thing‚Äô this month when it launches on March 5, marking Bungie‚Äôs long-awaited entry into the extraction shooter space. It‚Äôs going up against some monumental competition, especially in the form of both ARC Raiders and Escape from Tarkov, but tens of thousands of people have already gotten a taste of Marathon and (likely) want more.

At the time of writing, Marathon‚Äôs server slam product had a 24-hour peak player count of 76,437 users on Steam. This is how that stacks up against other, similar games on the platform:

  • ARC Raiders ‚Äì 227,765
  • Apex Legends ‚Äì 201,571
  • Marathon ‚Äì 76,437
  • Battlefield 6 ‚Äì 71,861
  • Call of Duty ‚Äì 52,575
  • Escape from Tarkov ‚Äì 19,220
  • Destiny 2 ‚Äì 11,623

The discourse around Marathon has been pretty mixed. There‚Äôs enough positivity there for the game to enjoy a semi-decent launch, but only if Bungie can deliver a strong roadmap and rapid enough updates. The team has already been addressing the game‚Äôs biggest gripes, including concerns around the complex UI, the lack of PvP, and optimization issues on PC platforms.

Unfortunately, Marathon is also going to be a game that lives or dies by its viewership, such is the life of extraction games. If the creators can get hooked, they‚Äôll retain an audience and keep feeding people into the game, but if that doesn‚Äôt happen, Marathon will surely plummet.

In the opening hours of the server slam, Marathon secured a peak of around 301,000 viewers on Twitch, and then, thanks to a huge push from popular streamers, it edged past that to hit 350,000 on Sunday, March 1. That was short-lived, though. The peak came at around 7 PM GMT, and by 10 PM GMT, only 70,000 people were watching the game.

It should be stressed that this isn‚Äôt a negative take of Marathon‚Äôs performance, as such. This is a game that could offer a sorely needed shake-up to the extraction genre, in a way that ARC Raiders managed to do in October 2025. It‚Äôs unique enough to leave a mark on the space, but the longevity of the thing is yet to be witnessed.

item.title: The Zoomer Obsession With DVDs Is A Blueprint For Saving Gaming
item.content:encoded:
Last week the Los Angeles Times reported on a surprising trend among young people. Physical media sales, DVDs especially, are experiencing a new burst of popularity. After a decade of freefall, enthusiasm among Gen Z halved a 20 percent sales decline in 2024 to just 9 percent in 2025. Stores have noticed. The Times‚Äô Karla Gachet spoke with staff at cultural hubs like Cinefile and Vidiots to discover why 2026 is already shaping up to be their biggest year, with the latter renting a surprising 1,000 DVDs a week.

It begs the question, could this pleasant trend take hold in video games too? ‚ÄúI definitely notice that younger people are actually interested in seeing where the game series of today first originated,‚Äù Daniel Teixeira of the long-running Toronto indie shop A&C Games tells Kotaku. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs cool how some are taking such a historical approach and paying respect to the roots.‚Äù

For DVDs, it‚Äôs no mystery. There‚Äôs a perfect storm for a new fascination with physical media. Big names like A24, Criterion, and Letterboxd are fostering a new generation of cinephiles who are engaging with more than just routine tentpole blockbusters. On the other end, Netflix and other major streamers are failing to service a generation that actually cares about film. They are raising fees and playing ads, all while the relentless streaming war consolidation is tossing back catalogues into a black hole.

The vinyl revival amongst millennials was partly about fidelity, partly about prestige. The return of DVDs is about necessity. The only practical way to dependably enjoy the films you love without corporate interruption is to own them on plastic. Add in some interesting third spaces to chat with like-minded folks and mill around in and suddenly you‚Äôve got a burgeoning new scene going.

The conditions rhyme in gaming. Mass distribution has overwhelmingly gone digital. Frustrations with curation, censorship and long-term access are as concerning here as anywhere else. The ennui from frictionless blockbuster releases is also clear. Players are picking up fewer games, and those who play the most are sticking with games released years ago. It has provoked the likes of Sony and Xbox into half-baked or shortsighted responses, like live service and AI, leading to results that will inevitably shrink both the industry and the diversity of releases, and intensify disinterest.

But there are gaping chasms between the two mediums as well. Film and music survive because of the efforts of movie houses, rental, and record shops. Games have historically thrived in permanent third spaces like stores and arcades, but those traditionally put commerce before culture. When you think of them, you think of how much, or how little, is in your wallet. Games culture has more recently thrived in competitive spaces and online file sharing sites, though digital spaces are even more precarious than real ones.

Teixeira shared these concerns. While young people are interested in exploring the past, the price point has been a barrier, making the pursuit ‚Äúelitist‚Äù as a result. ‚ÄúI feel bad at how much they need to spend to acquire physical copies,‚Äù says Teixeira. ‚ÄúEver since the pandemic, being able to collect older video games is far more difficult, particularly with whatever is most popular.‚Äù

It puts a lot of pressure on used stores, whose sellers need to respect rising prices to attract goods, even if it locks out younger fans. Correcting this negative feedback loop requires an unorthodox approach.

Diamonds in the rough

Since opening four years ago in San Bernardino County, RATNEST has also noticed the uptick in younger customers. ‚ÄúMy younger demo has seen a significant increase,‚Äù says store purveyor Robbie Ratnest. ‚ÄúEspecially with the kind of more obscure titles I carry involving anime, as well as the Japanese/Eastern horror, drama, tokusatsu, kaiju, etc. They‚Äôre very much looking for more than what modern media is offering for an average experience on top of it.‚Äù

RATNEST looks a little less like your traditional games store and more like a punk haunt. The original walls are lost behind a mosaic of stickers and old TV feeds. The lighting is dramatic, darkness pierced with bangs of purple and static hums. The trail of vintage games, arcade cabinets and vinyl is like a treasure hunt. Robbie tells me that after working in ‚Äúfar too many places that do not reflect what they claim to be about,‚Äù he wanted a space that reinforced the culture first, the cash second.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not here to make money, I make money to be here,‚Äù says Ratnest. ‚ÄúWe generally shun those who are very outspoken about flipping games or getting them graded. Absolutely do not give a shit about that. I want these games in people‚Äôs hands who want to enjoy them.‚Äù Even if it puts his retirement in peril, he‚Äôd rather games be enjoyed than fed into another speculative asset market that overshadows the entire scene.

Last fall I hit up the Toronto Game Expo, a retro convention, at the CNE grounds. When I buy, I don‚Äôt buy for commercial value. I already own the most valuable Nintendo 64 game. I have it because I was a weird kid who fished it out of Blockbuster‚Äôs $5 bin. I buy items that speak to me. A boxed copy of Myst for the Atari Jaguar CD. A strategy guide for Shinjuku Central Park Murder Case. Virtuoso. When one vendor asked what I was looking for, I said ‚Äúsomething interesting.‚Äù He immediately reached for his most expensive item. I respect the hustle, but it illustrates why games fail to foster themselves the way other mediums do.

Vinyl and film have their intense collectors too, obviously, but unlike in retro games they are not the norm. Likewise, even big box game stores have provided a community space. It‚Äôs no secret that GameStop can function like an after-school daycare, the former CEO even planning to install couches to help students settle in. But if you want to invest in games culture for the long haul, you‚Äôll have to put profiteering aside.

Once upon a time home media sales were half the battle. Box office busts like Blade Runner, Fight Club and The Thing were redeemed by VHS and DVD numbers over a lifetime. We‚Äôre still a ways out from restoring that ecosystem, and industries across entertainment are more short-term-profit-motivated than ever. But if you want games for 100 years over one, if you want off the live-service ride, it will require more imaginative thinking.

‚ÄúVideo games provide you with pieces of your future self in a way that other media cannot,‚Äù says Ratnest. ‚ÄúThat piece of that culture made from inspiration built upon inspiration will always overshadow the ‚Äòcollectability.'‚Äù

item.title: Marathon Is A Thrilling Shooter With A Big Onboarding Problem
item.content:encoded:
Marathon is brutal. That‚Äôs kind of the point. You play a futuristic gig economy worker paid by cyberpunk corpos who‚Äôs repeatedly getting murdered as you scavenge a dangerous, abandoned space colony for valuable gear, tech, and data. In a single-player game these vibes could be hitched to a meticulously calibrated campaign where every moment is carefully designed, engineered, and tested to keep things ultra-tense without repeatedly kicking the player‚Äôs teeth in. That‚Äôs a lot harder in a multiplayer game where every level comes with up to 18 super-sized human variables.

This is the promise of Marathon and also its curse. Play a couple of rounds and you will not be shocked to see that the game‚Äôs free beta weekend has a massive bounce rate on Steam as people try and it and seemingly don‚Äôt return. Bungie‚Äôs extraction shooter requires a lot of the player. They are at a severe disadvantage if they‚Äôre alone and not on the mic. Their characters start out weak and incredibly impaired. Sprinting quickly overheats your body. Even sliding at the wrong time can leave you hopelessly vulnerable.

yeah learning how to properly cycle through a map does a lot more for getting people into it then anything else I've found. and without any help learning how to do that is fucking Hard

‚Äî Paddy (@HorrorBuffPaddy) February 28, 2026

There are nuances to Marathon that are hard to immediately pick up on and the game routinely punishes you for being even a little dumb, impatient, or underprepared. You might think the point of the game is to drop into a match, kill tons of stuff, complete an objective, and escape with great loot. That‚Äôs what most other shooters have taught players, including Bungie‚Äôs own Destiny 2. In actuality, Marathon is about dropping down to a planet‚Äôs surface, hoarding your bullets like gold, and trying to avoid fights whenever and wherever possible.

Doing so will help you slowly accrue all the gear and upgrades you need to start projecting yourself as a real badass threat on Tau Ceti IV. Failing to do so will make you feel like you‚Äôre hitting your head against a wall and making no progress because you‚Äôre terrible at the game and playing it wrong. You might actually be terrible and you are definitely playing it wrong, but one of those things is fixable and can still lead to a lot of enjoyment with Marathon. But the game itself currently offers little in the way of guardrails to steer players into how to approach Marathon and have fun with it while they‚Äôre still figuring it out.

Please do not change / make drastic changes to make things easier.

The scarcity of resources + focus on stats makes this game completely unique and fun.

Overheat is literally solved through a skill tree and items, it's not even remotely a big deal.

‚Äî aaalex.hl (@aaalexhl) March 1, 2026

In some ways it‚Äôs like the opposite of Destiny 2. Bungie‚Äôs ongoing loot shooter, despite its notoriously convoluted and confusing early game, is overwhelmingly generous, showering players with rare gear and second chances at every turn. If I had one main criticism of the game in recent years it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs gotten too trivial at the bottom end of the grind. But Marathon is like if you introduced players to Destiny 2 by throwing them all into one of its end-game raids together. But also friendly fire was turned on, loot was scarce, and you only got to keep what you survived with.

That‚Äôs an incredibly bold and exciting way to shake things up, and also an experience designed to chew most people up and spit them out before they ever catch a whiff of what makes Marathon so special they might want to spend $40 on it. We‚Äôre in day four of the game‚Äôs free server slam and Bungie has kept reassuring players that it‚Äôs listening to feedback about how to re-tune everything from med pack and ammo economies to the gorgeous but overbearing UI, the lack of PVP, and heat generation during movement.

I think it‚Äôs easy to look at any of those and understand why they might make Marathon less fun for people. They certainly don‚Äôt make it easier to play. But they‚Äôre also all things you can start to rationalize and come around on the more you play, especially once you start trying to adapt to the game that‚Äôs actually in front of you rather than the one you‚Äôre expecting. Unfortunately, I think Marathon‚Äòs initial hostility will stop most people from ever getting to a place like that.

item.title: God of War developer is working on "a new franchise within the God of War universe"
item.content:encoded:
A former senior writer from Sony Santa Monica has revealed the studio is working on "a new franchise within the God of War universe".

The LinkedIn account that shared the news seems to no longer exist, but a screenshot of their profile, if real, suggests the team is developing the franchise beyond the God of War games we currently know.

The senior writer, who worked at the studio from 2020 until late last year, reportedly wrote on their LinkedIn profile that they had "helped shape narrative visions and creative direction and Sony Santa Monica Studio for a franchise within the God of War universe, developing characters, storylines, and original lore that expanded the acclaimed IP".

"Integrated story with gameplay and worldbuilding through scripts and narrative content, collaborating across disciplines to deliver emotionally driven experiences for a global audience," the blurb continued. "Contributed to long-term narrative and franchise strategy."

Given the original LinkedIn account has been deleted, there's no way to authenticate the claim, but it does tie in with prior reporting, including news that Bluepoint ‚Äì which was closed last week ‚Äì was developing a live service game within the God of War series.

Commenting on the ResetEra thread that shared the news late yesterday, Bloomberg's Jason Schreier wrote: "I suppose now it's become obvious what I meant by 'not a new IP but it might feel like one'".

Earlier this week, Amazon shared a first look at Ryan Hurst as Kratos in its God of War TV series. The picture showed Hurst leaning forward as he taught his son, Atreus, played by Callum Vinson, how to hunt. It's an image that echoes the opening scenes of the God of War reboot, released in 2018.

We hope those issues are fixed by the time the physical release rolls out, because the original Rayman deserves the best, hence its placement in the top three. For now, it gets a 7/10 from us.

According to dataminer PlayStation Game Size (@PlaystationSize on X), Rockstar Games has just added title IDs for Grand Theft Auto VI on Sony's PlayStation Store, possibly hinting at pre-orders opening in the near future:

Grand Theft Auto VI title IDs have been added to the PlayStation database. I expect we‚Äôll see something about the game soon, probably the start of pre-orders.

PlayStation Game Size regularly scrapes the PlayStation Store database searching for news and details about upcoming games. They'd previously discovered the placeholder date for God of War Ragnarok, September 30, 2022, which had been entered into the PlayStation Store, and it turned out to be not far from the actual release date, November 11, 2022. The fact that Rockstar Games has started doing preparatory work on Grand Theft Auto VI's store page will undoubtedly reinvigorate the hopes of fans, who are eager to see the studio confirm the November 19, 2026 date. There have already been two delays, after all, from Fall 2025 to May 26, 2026, and then again to November. item.title: Resident Evil Requiem's Steam concurrent peak is the biggest in franchise history
item.content:encoded:
Resident Evil Requiem is likely now the biggest Resident Evil game in the franchise's history, sporting a concurrent player count on Steam high enough to rival even multiplayer games.

At the time of writing, single-player Resident Evil Requiem has an all-time concurrent peak of 344,214 players on Steam alone, over double that of Resident Evil 4 Remake, and three times that of predecessor Resident Evil Village.

Resident Evil 2 Remake, on the other hand, has a Steam peak of 74,227 players, Resident Evil 3 a peak of 60,293, and Resident Evil 7, 20,449.

That 344,214 player peak is also bigger than the all-time Steam concurrent records of multiplayer games like Destiny 2 (316,750), Elden Ring Nightreign (313,593), and Monster Hunter: World (334,684).

Of course, concurrent peaks do not reflect players jumping into the action on other platforms ‚Äì or even via other PC stores like Epic Games Store ‚Äì so cannot be taken in isolation, but it's typically a good indication of popularity. It also shows that Capcom has sold at least 344,214 copies in Requiem's debut weekend.

As spoilers popped all over the Internet, prompting Capcom to acknowledge the situation ahead of the final weekend before the game's launch, Resident Evil 2 director Hideki Kamiya had some choice words for the leakers, suggesting "they are cursed to never play the game again."

"Is Requiem uneven? Absolutely. Does it eventually, slightly, run out of steam? I think that's a fair criticism, too. But carried away on a wave of increasing nostalgia, I didn't especially care," Matt wrote in his 5/5 Eurogamer Resident Evil Requiem review.

item.title: Zen And The Art Of Van Maintenance Meets Firewatch In Steam Next Fest Hit Cozy Survival Sim Outbound
item.content:encoded:
There‚Äôs a game I love called The Long Dark. It‚Äôs a relentless survival sim that pits you against the elements out in the wilderness. You can starve, freeze to death, or get mauled by a pack of wild wolves. It has this oppressive, foreboding vibe to it that few games can match. Outbound is kind of the cozy sim version of that. 

I played the Steam Next Fest demo for Outbound, a campervan driving survival game from developers Square Glade Games, and it feels like someone ran The Long Dark through a Pixar filter. These two games share so much in common: light crafting elements, a need to scavenge to fill your stomach, an intentionally light focus on your sense of direction, and that lonely feeling of living within a world that other people have left behind.

And yet, Outbound is also kind of the very antithesis of The Long Dark. You get hungry, sure, but you won‚Äôt starve to death: you‚Äôll just pass out. The world is devoid of human interaction, but there‚Äôs plenty of cute little animals to make friends with instead (and a co-op mode I, ironically, couldn‚Äôt convince a friend to try with me). You can‚Äôt even run the animals over with your massive, unwieldy campervan. Trust me, I tried. There‚Äôs friction but the world isn‚Äôt out to make you fail.

Strangely, that‚Äôs what I loved about my three hours with Outbound, whose demo is one of the most popular of February‚Äôs Steam Next Fest. It‚Äôs an easy, breezy experience. It‚Äôs a survival game about trying your best to live as opposed to one about desperately trying not to die. There‚Äôs really no wrong way to play it, either, because the focus is on, if you‚Äôll excuse the pun, simply enjoying the ride. You‚Äôre not even really tasked with accomplishing any specific goals. Sometimes you‚Äôll get a prompt telling you there‚Äôs a new schematic you can unlock or a location you‚Äôve yet to visit, but there‚Äôs always this ‚Äúonly if you want to‚Äù mentality to it all. Outbound won‚Äôt scream at you for playing it the wrong way, because there‚Äôs no right way to begin with.

There are plenty of silly systems to interact with, though, if you so choose. You can build a big house, start your own farm, or even amass a friendly army of bunnies by feeding them heaps of berries. All of these mechanics are straightforward to use and, most importantly, extremely forgiving. If all you wanna do is munch on some wild mushrooms and sit by a fire with your dog, Outbound doesn‚Äôt care, man. Put your hulking brute of a motorhome in park and just watch the sunset go down if you want, dude. No wolves are gonna rip you limb from limb once the moon appears, bro. Just pet the cute bunnies and let the chill, outdoor vibes wash over you.

I saw a few reviews poke fun at Outbound for being ‚Äúcozyslop,‚Äù and my heart goes out to those poor souls. Do we always need a deep endgame or a grand cause to work toward? Does there have to be a destination? Because if you go into Outbound expecting Dark Souls meets Burnout, you‚Äôre gonna come away disappointed (even though that sounds sick). But if you go in expecting Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance mixed with Firewatch, you‚Äôll get what you came for: a relaxing game about doing nothing in particular. I‚Äôm already looking forward to cozy-friend-slopmaxxing my Outbound playthrough when the full release drops sometime before summer 2026.

‚ÄúArknights: Endfield‚Äòs global player count, playtime, and in-game activity levels have all greatly exceeded our expectations,‚Äô and Version 1.1 serves as a direct response to the community‚Äôs rapid engagement,‚Äù said producer Light Zhong in a press release.

Here are the patch notes:

New Content

Several additional operators will be added alongside an expansion of the evolving AIC system via the new hydro-industrialization system.

  • New Operators
    • Tangtang (6-star Caster) ‚Äì Described as a ‚Äúone-girl team,‚Äù Tangtang is specialized in AOE Cryo damage and support. Her Ultimate, DA CHIEF SEES YOU!, introduces a powerful new tactical layer by immobilizing all enemies within its range ‚Äì including bosses ‚Äì allowing her squads to create decisive damage windows.
    • Rossi (6-star Guard) ‚Äì The only operator currently capable of converting Arts Infliction on enemies into Vulnerability (defense break). This specialized mechanic positions her as a vital force multiplier for Physical-focused squads, as she shreds enemy defenses to facilitate massive damage output from the team‚Äôs primary carries.
  • Hydro-Industrialization
    • New Tech ‚Äì The Hydro Mining Rig allows players to mine Cuprium, a new industrial resource that uses water flow instead of electricity. Unlike existing facilities, Hydro Mining Rigs harness water flow to automate mineral collection, requiring no connection to the power grid.
    • New Logistics ‚Äì New Conduits for long-distance liquid transport and Water Treatment Units for processing sewage.
      Forges of the Sky Expansion: Placement limit for Forges of the Sky increased to four units, significantly raising the production ceiling for endgame resources.
  • World and Story Expansions
    • New Wuling Area ‚Äì Qingbo Stockade
    • Story ‚Äì The Endministrator can investigate the Qingbo Stockade, where tensions with Wuling City are boiling over due to the arrival of Nefarith and Ardashir.

Player Rewards and Progression

In addition to the launch window offering of 135 free pulls, player rewards will now be supplemented by:

  • New Beginner Support ‚Äì After reaching specific milestones in Chapter 1, players will receive a new beginner mission reward totalling 10 Chartered Headhunting Permits. Endministrators who have already completed these requirements can claim their rewards directly from the event page upon the update.
  • Sign-In Events ‚Äì ‚ÄúGently Flows Qingbo‚Äù and ‚ÄúPearl of the Pack‚Äù (7-day logins) for limited-time permits.
    Battle Pass Update: The Protocol Pass now allows for periodic acquisition of Basic Headhunting Permits.
  • Limited-time Activities
    • Exploration Day ‚Äì Farming at Originium Science Park.
    • Survival Training ‚Äì Try a different take on combat using only Industrial Explosives!
  • Systemic Rewards ‚Äì AIC Quota acquisition has been expanded, with players now receiving Quotas for obtaining 4, 5, and 6-star operators for the first time. For operators acquired prior to the update, the corresponding Quotas will be distributed via in-game mail.
  • Advanced Gear Optimization ‚Äì The introduction of the Valley Multi-Line Engraving Kit ‚Äì available through the Stock Redistribution system‚Äîallows players to create Essences with three customized stats. This provides a high-level path for Endministrators to optimize endgame weapon builds and reduce RNG friction.

Community-Driven Optimizations

Following launch feedback, Version 1.1 introduces sweeping improvements to the user experience, particularly for controller players.

  • Construction Precision ‚Äì The buffer range for power lines has been extended to 20m (100m total), and connection will no longer snap during dialogue or combat triggers. Controller users can also now move facilities by long-pressing a dedicated button.

The expansion of Talos-II will continue at an even larger scale in Version 1.2. The upcoming narrative arc will see the Endministrator join forces with Tianshi Zhuang to defend the Xiranite Dam against a sudden siege by Ardashir. This future update will introduce two new maps, an outpost, and a new fluid-based production system for the AIC Factory.

Add your thoughts in the UI thread on our Discord so we can track them all in one place: https://discord.com/channels/1303855380845301861/1476673733358915778
  • PC performance: We are reviewing reports of high CPU use, low GPU utilisation, FPS ceilings ~80‚Äì100, and some stuttering.   • PvP frequency: As we continue to keep an ear to the ground on this one, we‚Äôre further investigating total player density on non-beginner maps to cover all of our bases. If you've got any feedback - be it on Perimeter (Beginner), Perimeter, or Dire Marsh - we want to hear it!
  • Movement and heat generation: As the test continues on, we‚Äôve seen continued discussions about heat generation, momentum, and overall movement feedback. Make sure to take a chance and let us know your thoughts!

Keep sharing your experiences and please let us know what you brought into any runs where you feel like you‚Äôre running dry.

item.title: Feature: 30 Pok√©mon You Probably Forgot That Deserve A Second Chance
item.content:encoded:
Given Pok√©mon‚Äôs roaring popularity for three decades straight, it‚Äôs a sheer numbers game to figure that each of its titular beasts is someone‚Äôs favourite. It‚Äôs also true that over 1,000 Pok√©mon can‚Äôt all share the limelight, meaning some are bound to fade into obscurity.

While the most popular Pok√©mon take centre stage for the franchise‚Äôs 30th anniversary, I figured space should be made to honour the Pok√©Misfits that didn‚Äôt stand the test of time. These include oddities that only the staunchest Pok√© Maniacs will recall, others of minor notoriety that deserve more love, and phased-out mascots. While they may be easily written off as sideshows, these Pok√©mon still played roles (in some cases, infamously) in keeping the franchise on top for all these years.

Before jumping in, a quick note: I left out Gen 9 'newcomers' as their legacies are still being written. I also had regional variants, mega evolutions, and their ilk take a seat to keep the proceedings simpler.

30 Pok√©Misfits That Deserve More Love

First up, Pok√©Who?

This category covers Pok√©mon that many straight-up forgot about. They‚Äôre sure to have their fans ‚Äî that‚Äôs true of any Pok√©mon ‚Äî but by and large, they never caught on, or only enjoyed fleeting relevancy...

Shedinja (#292)

If there‚Äôs one element of the Pok√©mon fandom that I‚Äôll forever miss, it‚Äôs the schoolyard tall tales that kids told each other when we didn‚Äôt have easy internet access. By Gen 3, scepticism had set in, making me disbelieve Shedinja‚Äôs existence.

I have to keep a spot in my party empty and have a spare Pok√© Ball to obtain it? Sounded about as likely as finding Mew under a truck!

Of course, it does work‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs about the most I can say. Schoolyard chatter quickly moved on to new leaks and lies. Shedinja‚Äôs allure became its undoing as myths were far more compelling than truths. It‚Äôs now notable as a historical footnote and its unique Bug/Ghost dual-typing. That‚Äôs more than can be said for a lot of the entries in this category, but nonetheless disappointing for such a conceptually cool Pok√©mon.

Klinklang #601

There‚Äôs not a lot working in Klinklang‚Äôs favour. Its design is simultaneously basic, even among Gen 5‚Äôs wave of inanimate object Pok√©mon, and also derivative of Magneton. It‚Äôs therefore not too surprising that this gearhead wouldn‚Äôt leave much of an impact.

However, I do believe it has the potential to earn a renewed residency in the minds of fans by having it utilise its utilitarian design to help keep the Pok√©mon world running. For example, imagine a city running on Klinglang-powered machinery, or gadgets that could be brought alive by a Klinglang in your party.

That sort of worldbuilding is what Klinglang is destined for.

Zarude #893

This mythical primate was never made available beyond a few online distribution events that occurred a year or more after the release of Sword and Shield (let alone after both its expansion packs were available). It‚Äôs highly possible that most Sword and Shield players never even learned of Zarude‚Äôs existence because of its late addition. Many who did still had a hard time finding love in their heart for this monkey due to a lack of an in-game event to give it the context it desperately needed.

Zarude could see a renaissance if The Pok√©mon Company decides to reintroduce it with expanded prominence, but for now, it‚Äôs a bit of a non-entity.

Dhelmise #781

The concept behind Dhelmise is cool enough: a rusty, seaweed-strapped anchor that can supposedly knock out Wailord in one attack (Pok√©mon battles don‚Äôt back up this claim). The reality is that it‚Äôs ultimately just a possessed anchor, something that wasn‚Äôt particularly novel by the time of its Gen 7 introduction.

It‚Äôs well themed for the tropical Alolan archipelago, but then again, so are many of that region‚Äôs newcomers. Still, I give props to Game Freak for giving wacky ideas like this a shot, even if they don‚Äôt always catch on. For better or worse, they can‚Äôt all be Garbodor.

Maractus #556

As the second Cactus Pok√©mon to lay its roots in the franchise, Maractus needed a bit more going for it to stand out. Namely, it‚Äôs a type of single-evolution Pok√©mon that feels like it shouldn‚Äôt be standalone. The design concept of maracas growing out of its head is the perfect setup for an evolution to run with.

Without one, it felt like borderline Gen. 5 filler added so that generation wouldn't include any old monsters until its post-game. I hoped that Legends Z-A might‚Äôve given it a plus-up in the form of a mega evolution, but with that opportunity gone, who knows if Maractus will ever get the treatment it deserves.

Huntail #367 and Gorebyss #368

These two share an evolutionary base Pok√©mon in the adorable Clamperl, yet neither share in its fandom. In fact, it wasn‚Äôt until researching for this article that I remembered Clamperl even had evolutions at all!

Perhaps that‚Äôs because both require trading, which has always been a somewhat frustrating (even if understandably flavourful) barrier to using certain Pok√©mon, especially if you‚Äôre a solo player like me. I have to imagine that‚Äôs also true for many others whose only encounters with Huntail and Gorebyss came through trainer battles or rare in-the-wild scenarios.

It‚Äôs a shame because these groovy, psychedelic eels have been waiting over two decades for their moment in the sun. Or perhaps they just prefer the deep ocean, in which case, live your best lives, sea misfits.

Stakataka #805

The alien nature of Ultra Beasts makes them all inherent misfits of the Pok√©mon universe, but that‚Äôs also why some have been fondly remembered. Stakataka isn‚Äôt usually part of those conversations, though. Its stone colossus design isn‚Äôt particularly original or memorable, especially when you consider that The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild introduced the strikingly similar Guardians months prior.

Plus, appearing exclusively in 3DS games that launched after the Switch rocked the world was a surefire way to not rock the world. Still, if Ultra Beasts ever come back, Stakataka might find its footing.

The Gen. 8 Fossil Quartet (Dracozolt #880, Arctozolt #881, Dracovish #882, and Arctovish #883)

Uhhhhhhh, so yeah.

First, for those keeping count at home, this is one of two scenarios where I‚Äôm lumping all four of these‚Ä¶ Pok√©mon?... into one listing since they‚Äôre all cut from the same cloth of combining two fossils to create genetic monstrosities.

The Frankenstein creations that this resulted in might be more believable as something found in Silent Hill. In fact, their mere existence is that level of unsettling, which I suppose will be the feature for many players. For others, we‚Äôd rather forget.

That said, I‚Äôm open-minded. Game Freak, game on. The ball‚Äôs in your court to make me love these patchwork Pok√©mon.

Next up, The Under-Appreciated Misfits.

The Pok√©mon in this category have a steady presence in the franchise but don‚Äôt get the love they deserve. Whether they live in infamy or are overshadowed by their immediate peers, let‚Äôs give these beasties a second look on the second page...
